avalancheActivity.highlights: New snow fell in SE winds this week. Minor snowfall then fell in northerly winds followed rain in the mountains on Thursday. The snowpack has melted considerably and gotten stronger but small unstable wind slabs as well as cornices could be present in gullies and depressions.

snowpackStructure.highlights: New snow fell in SE winds during the week. Snow melted considerably on Thursday in a rainy weather in the mountains followed by minor snowfall early on Friday. New snow could bind poorly with older snow and small wind slabs or cornices could form around terrain traps. Older snow is widely considered stable and cohesive after several melt-freeze cycles in recent weeks. This had less effect higher in the mountains and unstable wind slabs or cornices have likely grown there in various aspects.

travelAdvisory.comment: The snowpack is currently very unstable in the Westfjords and Tröllaskagi regions. A blizzard passed the regions in N-NE winds on Thursday and Friday and avalanche danger is high. Weak layers have been detected in the snowpack and it could take a few days for the snowpack to develop and settle. Many natural slab avalanches have been falling in both regions and people traveling in the mountains should practice caution and avoid steep hills.
travelAdvisory.highlights: The snowpack is currently very unstable in the Westfjords and Tröllaskagi regions. A blizzard passed the regions in N-NE winds on Thursday and Friday and avalanche danger is high.

weatherForecast.highlights: Hæglætis veður og úrkomulaust næstu daga. Hlýnar aðeins á mánudag en frystir aftur með vikunni.

avalancheActivity.comment: Many avalanches fell in the region after a N-NE blizzard at the end of the week. Multiple slab avalanches were also reported on Monday and Tuesday 18.3. and 19.3. The largest was size 3 in Dýrafjörður.
avalancheActivity.highlights: N and NE snowstorm passed the region in the last days and natural avalanches have widely fallen. A lot of snow has drifted into SE - NW aspects but the snowpack is unstable in all aspects.

snowpackStructure.highlights: Last week, a lot of snow fell in two consecutive NE blizzards. Unstable wind slabs formed and multiple avalanches released in the region. Snow pits from the region confirm the presence of unstable wind slabs with stiff melt-freeze snow beneath. Weak layers have been detected within the new snow but also between the new snow and the older snow. Several avalanches fell in the region after the first storm this week and also on Friday after the second storm. The wind slabs in SE - NW aspects have grown considerably and are unstable. People should avoid steep terrain while the snowpack is adjusting after the storm.

travelAdvisory.comment: The snowpack is currently very unstable in the Westfjords and Tröllaskagi regions. A blizzard passed the regions in N-NE winds on Thursday and Friday and avalanche danger is high. Many natural slab avalanches have been falling in both regions and people traveling in the mountains should practice caution and avoid steep hills.

weatherForecast.highlights: NA og N hríðarveður gekk yfir svæðið seinnipart föstudags eftir mikla snjókomu og skafrenning. Lægir með helginni og úrkomulaust að mestu en búist er við lítilsháttar NA snjókomu með þriðjudeginum. Frost 8-12 stig til fjalla.

avalancheActivity.comment: Several slab avalanches have occurred in the area in recent days. An avalanche released on the road to Kleifar in Ólafsfjörður and out into the sea on Friday morning. Two major avalanches fell on the road from Dalvík to Ólafsfjörður night before Saturday. Additionally, an avalanche fell on the road to Siglufjörður west of the Strákagöng tunnel. Two size 3 and 3.5 avalanches released above Dalvík on the night to Saturday. Avalanches of size 2-3.5 occurred in Ólafsfjörður, specifically in Arnfinnsfjall, Ósbrekkufjall, Auðnahyrna, and Bustabrekkudal, likely releasing night before Saturday or Friday.
avalancheActivity.highlights: A lot of new snow is in the area. It can be expected that the new snow will remain unstable, with thick wind drifts found in most aspects, especially southern aspects. Human triggered avalanches are likely to occur.

snowpackStructure.highlights: The snow is unstable across the region following strong northerly winds and heavy snowfall since Thursday. A snow profile taken from Klettahnjúkur on March 23rd showed significant instability in the new snow layers and at interfaces with underlying layers. A propagation saw test indicated propagation at 35 cm, and extended column tests showed planar fractures under moderate loads. New snow may remain unstable, as several avalanches have occurred in the area in recent days. Those venturing into the mountains are urged to proceed with caution and adhere to good travel practices. The snowpack remains unstable, with a risk of human-triggered avalanches. Further assessments of the stability of the new snow are crucial as the week progresses.

Many natural slab avalanches have been falling in both regions and people traveling in the mountains should practice caution and avoid steep hills.

weatherForecast.highlights: Áfram éljagangur til fjalla og N-NA 6- 10 næstu daga.

avalancheActivity.comment: Several avalanches occurred in the area during the week, including slab avalanches caused by snowmobilers in Fannardalur on March 20th, natural slab avalanches from Norðfjörður on March 19th, and in Eskifjörður on March 15th. In addition, several smaller avalanches, both loose snow avalanches and slab avalanches, have occurred.
avalancheActivity.highlights: A considerable amount of snow has fallen in the northern slopes during snowfall since Friday. Unstable wind slabs could be present on most aspects, but there is little snow in the lower part of the mountains, so wind slabs are primarily found at higher elevations.

snowpackStructure.highlights: Thick wind slabs are present on southerly aspects following the northerly winds on Friday and Saturday. The snow depth is highest above Neskaupstaður and Seyðisfjörður, and unstable wind gusts are likely to be found widely in the mountains. Last week, wind slabs formed during northerly directions, resulting in a layered snowpack, and weaknesses are likely to be found at the interfaces. The underlying layers are considered relatively stable, and there is little snow in the lower parts of the mountains due to thaw.

travelAdvisory.comment: The snowpack is currently very unstable in the Westfjords and Tröllaskagi regions.
